Title: Linking forum posts - Maps-001-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.threadtitle: use of the maps in lesson 1
Input.posts:
I'm just wondering if the maps used in lesson 1 are typical of maps used by professionals. For example, the ecoregions layer was very busy with so many color codings that many of the colors were similar, at least to me. I ended up having to click on a block to try to differentiate what type of region it was instead of being able to visually sort it out. I was trying to go through the exercise of trying to match population against ecoregions. But, clicking on each region seems to me very inefficient. Or am I not navigating through the information correctly?
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
This is an interesting question. I’ve been working as an environmental scientist for over 10 years – so I qualify as a “professional”. I use this sort of data all of the time. If a map end product (for a report, for example) isn’t going to be produced, the color coding (or symbology) demonstrated in the exercise isn’t really important. If I was going to create a map product, I might consider using a different palette. In the example of this exercise, I would typically do what you did: select an area and then report the results if I only needed information for a few places. There are a number of ways to get the answers for multiple sites using common GIS tools. I think this was actually a pretty interesting introductory exercise and efficiency wasn’t the point.

The quiz scoring indicates that we should have said the geospatial revolution has not lead to a major transformation in three areas that have changed dramatically because of geospatial information: 1. How we print maps . As a graphic designer, this one leaps out to me. The information processing revolution that facilitated the geospatial revolution also resulted in print-on-demand technology. This quick, short run digital printing has combined with the products of the geospatial revolution to produce a radical transformation in the way maps are printed. Four color lithography still has a place, but we now live in a world with phrases like ' NOAA certified print-on-demand partners ' ( http://www.gisuser.com/content/view/31279/2/ ) --such a concept was inconceivable before the geospatial revolution. This is but one of many examples, such as the circumstances behind the environmentally tragic loss of the USS Guardian, that show that the geospatial revolution has transformed the way we print (and sometimes don't print) maps. 2. How we design globes. The same factors that resulted in print-on-demand maps give us custom globes. Vendors offer satellite imagery on globes with custom data sets overlayed... the fruit of the geospatial revolution. http://www.maps-eureka.com/custom-globes.html http://www.capitalplasticsco.com/product-gallery/custom-globes/ 3. How boundaries are drawn. I suppose this is debatable because it comes down to what kind of boundaries are in question. If you were mapping the spread of a disease, like the tragic UN introduced Cholera outbreak in Haiti, for example, your approach to defining the boundaries of the impacted area would be very different post geospatial revolution than pre geospatial revolution. Boundaries on traditional maps often have significant errors and geospatial data can be and is used to correct these boundaries all the time. The case of the USS Guardian comes to mind again, in reference to this. I answered yes to these three and then was marked wrong...

The quiz scoring indicates that we should have said the geospatial revolution has not lead to a major transformation in three areas that have changed dramatically because of geospatial information: 1. How we print maps . As a graphic designer, this one leaps out to me. The information processing revolution that facilitated the geospatial revolution also resulted in print-on-demand technology. This quick, short run digital printing has combined with the products of the geospatial revolution to produce a radical transformation in the way maps are printed. Four color lithography still has a place, but we now live in a world with phrases like ' NOAA certified print-on-demand partners ' ( http://www.gisuser.com/content/view/31279/2/ ) --such a concept was inconceivable before the geospatial revolution. This is but one of many examples, such as the circumstances behind the environmentally tragic loss of the USS Guardian, that show that the geospatial revolution has transformed the way we print (and sometimes don't print) maps. 2. How we design globes. The same factors that resulted in print-on-demand maps give us custom globes. Vendors offer satellite imagery on globes with custom data sets overlayed... the fruit of the geospatial revolution. http://www.maps-eureka.com/custom-globes.html http://www.capitalplasticsco.com/product-gallery/custom-globes/ 3. How boundaries are drawn. I suppose this is debatable because it comes down to what kind of boundaries are in question. If you were mapping the spread of a disease, like the tragic UN introduced Cholera outbreak in Haiti, for example, your approach to defining the boundaries of the impacted area would be very different post geospatial revolution than pre geospatial revolution. Boundaries on traditional maps often have significant errors and geospatial data can be and is used to correct these boundaries all the time. The case of the USS Guardian comes to mind again, in reference to this. I answered yes to these three and then was marked wrong...
